lines: MR NIKOLAS GEORGIOU
PRESIDENT:  Mr Georgiou, you should have in front of you
a card that's got an oath.
WITNESS:  Yep, I do.
PRESIDENT:  If you could put your hand on whichever holy
book you're going to use and read the oath.
WITNESS:  Yes, of course.  I swear promise by almighty God
that the evidence I shall give will be the truth, the
whole truth and nothing but the truth.
I swear promise that I have followed and I will
follow the tribunal's procedures regarding the accuracy,
truthfulness and fairness of my evidence to the best of
my ability.
PRESIDENT:  Thank you very much.  Mr Hickey will now ask you
some questions, after which Mr Catchpole will ask you
some questions.
Examination-in-chief by MR HICKEY
MR HICKEY:  Good morning, Mr Georgiou.  Could you please,
for the benefit on the transcript, state your full name?
A.  My name is Nikolas Georgiou.
Q.  Mr Georgiou, I think you have made two witness
statements and I think you have in front of you a hard
copy of both of them that's unmarked.  Can you confirm
that, please?
A.  Yeah, confirmed.
Q.  Also on the screen, it will come up, are the electronic
copies of that, at B11 to start with?
A.  Yeah.
Q.  Do you recognise that as your first witness statement?
A.  Correct.
Q.  If we could go to the signature page, please.
A.  That's my signature.
Q.  Thank you very much.  Have you read it recently?
A.  Yeah, I did.
Q.  Are its contents true and the evidence you wish to give
in respect of that statement?
A.  Yes, they are.
Q.  You gave a subsequent second statement.  Could you look
at that, please.  It's at B24.
A.  Yes.
Q.  Can you confirm that's your second statement?
A.  Yeah, it is.
Q.  And could you go to the signature page on page 39,
please.
A.  That's my signature.
Q.  That's your signature?
A.  Yeah, it is.
Q.  Have you read it recently?
A.  Yeah, I did.
Q.  Are it's contents true and the evidence you wish to give
to the tribunal in respect of that statement?
A.  Yes, they are.
MR HICKEY:  Thank you very much, Mr Georgiou.  Mr Catchpole
will have a few questions.
Cross-examination by MR CATCHPOLE
MR CATCHPOLE:  Good morning Mr Georgiou, apologies if I get
your name as well, I haven't had as much practice as
Mr Hickey.
My function is to test your evidence, it's not to
try and catch you out or do anything like that.  So if
anything is unclear or you want the question put again
or to look at documents, please say so.  All right?
A.  Yeah, sure.
Q.  We're going to cover -- we have covered quite a lot of
the issues that you touch on in your evidence with other
witnesses, so we won't be dealing with everything that's
in your witness statement.
But can I start just chronologically with your
introduction to the project.  You say you arrive -- and
you're an electrical engineer by background; is that
right?
A.  Correct.
Q.  You arrive on the project in October 2018?
Q.  If we could look, please, at D2724.
A.  In my witness statement?
Q.  No, sorry.  When I give a reference, it's to a document.
A.  Okay.
Q.  Which will come up on the screen.
A.  Okay.  Because it was not there.  Okay.
Q.  Yes, sometimes it takes, there's a little lag.
Now, this is just before you arrive, but I imagine
it would be something you would have seen as the person
in charge of the MEP in the hotel.  27 September 2018,
the JV is writing to Specon saying:
"We refer to the above Project and express serious
concerns regarding your poor performance in the Hotel
sector."
So that's your sector that you're walking into; is
that right?
A.  Correct.
Q.  "As highlighted in numerous Site meetings both
internally and with the Client your performance in the
Hotel sector is not acceptable and is at a rate of
progress that we consider to be too slow for you to
complete your Subcontract Works within your Time For
Completion.
Unforeseen engineering issues are being raised on an
almost daily basis, protracted period to resolve is
causing direct delay to the release of both Ceiling and
wall closure, a non-exhaustive list below ..."
It's got wall closures, raised three weeks ago, and:
"... due to lack of follow up from your team the
wall closures at the Vanity in all Hotel Guest room
toilets is on hold."
Expansion/contraction calculation, delay in
submission of these for the drainage system is currently
delaying the closure of the shaft walls in all hotel
guest rooms.
"3.  FCU flexible connection - As per specification,
FCU flexible connection must be 100 mm.  However, Specon
has installed 75 mm flexible connection on site.  SBJV
persuaded the designer and DEC to allow the installation
for a limited amount of rooms in order to allow for
subsequent activities.  However, the installation of 75
mm flexible connection continues on site which clearly
indicates a disconnect between the engineering
department and the site team.
4.  Chilled water valves - The MAR for chilled water
valves was approved.  However, the material delivered on
site were not as per approved MAR.  Agreed mutually with
DEC that the valves be accepted for site installations
with the condition that all the valves installed at site
be one type.  However, the next delivery was of a
different type of valve again creating delays.
5.  Uncontrolled issuance of drawings to site
leading to installations carried out not as per approved
shop drawings, which were in place, namely the HVAC
system.  Your procedure if existing for issuing
information/drawings to the site team is to be updated,
issued and strictly followed."
It goes over the page:
"6.  FCU Link - On 05.09.18 SBJV team discovered
that the FCU link delivered to site was accompanied by
no supporting documentation which could establish the
country of origin or details pertaining to the entry of
the material to the UAE.  Over two weeks have elapsed
and to date there has been no MAR submitted for a
different manufacturer, this is totally unacceptable ...
7.  Manpower - The manpower requirement assessment
for the Hotel Sector prepared by our team based on your
past performance is attached for guidance and your
perusal.  It has been acknowledged by the Senior
Management of Specon over the past days that a
significant increase in manpower is required on site to
achieve the agreed targets as such you are to issue your
mobilisation plan for the Hotel Section by close of
business on 7th October ..."
Obviously that's a fairly lengthy list of criticisms
of Specon's performance as at that date; is that right?
Serious criticisms of their performance at that date?
A.  As you said, I was not there.
Q.  But this is what you're facing when you come in; is that
right?
A.  When I joined, it came to my attention from the higher
management that I needed to push this job to move
forward, since when I joined, it was the time that the
job was starting to push up the bar.
I joined, as you previously said, 2018, and I left
the site November, when they release us.  So that means
that I was there for most of the time.
As you can see in my witness statement, the progress
and the outcome from my three and a half years on that
site, it was progressively that good.
Q.  We'll come to that.  I just want you to answer the
question.  When you were walking in, in October 2018,
you are walking in to taking over in circumstances where
the JV is being deeply critical about Specon's
performance in the hotels up to that point in time?
A.  That's normal.  In all construction sites.
Q.  Is the answer "yes" or "no"?  You are walking in and the
JV is being deeply critical of Specon's performance up
to the point that you have arrived?
A.  No, I disagree.
Q.  Could you look at D2546.  This is an email, again
towards the end of September.  It says -- it's to
everyone:
"All,
We remain slipping in progress 12 months from Soft
Opening -- Here are some Notes on this regard for your
best actions ..."
"Fit Out", and it says, if one goes to number 2:
"Over 160 Nos of Rooms Handed Over by ISHTAR for
Specon Walls and Ceilings Progress;
3.  0 Nos of 100% Room Wall Clearance for ISHTAR
Closure by Specon -- Reported Nos intend to demonstrate
Dry Areas only;
4.  Corridors and Core Area BOH Rooms -- Lack of
Progress -- ISHTAR & Specon -- Update/[four-week]
Lookahead to be provided next Monday ..."
Is this fair, by the time you arrive, what the JV is
saying, at least, is you've got work fronts available
and you are not progressing the works properly?
A.  This is what it says, the email, the letter, correct.
Q.  So you're walking into something where there's a lot of
pressure on you to actually try and catch up, to
overcome delays, and to organise Specon to rectify the
problems in the performance that had been identified; is
that right?
A.  That's my job, yeah.
Q.  D2591, please.  We see -- sorry, just go up so we can
see who's there.  It's Mr Almeida from the JV to a raft
of people and he is identifying that, in 3:
"Additional Teams need to be created:
a. to avoid further slippage on MEP Side - 343
Rooms Wall Clearance (Wet/Dry) Target for 6 Nov.2018;
b. to accommodate progress in Cantilever &
Skycourts by C6 ISHTAR and F1 Side for all
activities ..."
Saying that -- is this right, you were being told
you needed to get additional resources on site?
A.  Could you please go up on that letter?
Q.  Yes.
A.  Thank you.  I was not copied on this email.
Q.  No, I'm trying to work out what you were facing,
because -- when you come in, because it then affects how
things progress.
Were you being told when you arrive in October: you
need to get additional resources to try and stop further
slippage in the progress of the MEP works?
A.  I was told in the war rooms, correct.
Q.  Mr Darla of Specon is copied to this email.  He was your
predecessor, was he?
A.  Zoran, yes, correct.
Q.  What happened to him?
A.  He was -- after I joined the hotel, he was being
removed.
Q.  Yes, he was sacked for non-performance; is that right?
A.  I don't know if it's bad performance, but he was
removed.
Q.  Anyway, if we look at D2616, please.  Again, Mr Sabri
this time, end of September, site walk commitment,
saying:
"Today not good result see the following update:
- Duct flexible installation today target/ zero out
of 10.
- Duct flexible installation yesterday 6 rooms
update was wrong/target room ..."
They are doing work in the wrong room:
"... done at the site ... not in yesterday or today
target ...
- Rectification works for 2nd 17 rooms/3 rooms
completed out of 05 without duct flexible
connection ..."
And it goes on.  You must have been a bit shocked,
I imagine, to find yourself walking into this sort of
failure properly to organise the works by Specon; is
that fair?
A.  Not really.
Q.  Could you please go forward to look at a slightly
different point.  We're going to go through over time,
so don't worry, we'll come back to your performance.
Just so we're clear, I accept, Mr Georgiou, you do get
on top of things, you do try and progress things.  I'm
not suggesting you personally were causing lots of
problems.
But just looking at a slightly different issue.
Your first witness statement, paragraph 4.12, B11,
page 10.  This is slightly curious evidence.  You say in
paragraph 4.12:
"When I joined the Project in November 2018, SBJV
had issued a Rev 07 Programme dated 9 January 2018
however this programme was not a primavera programme
like the Rev 06 Baseline Programme but rather just
showed the MEP activities.  SBJV then issued two further
revised programmes which again only showed the MEP
activities.  These were the:
"(a) Rev 08 Programme dated 27 February..."
Then you say in 4.13:
"To my knowledge, we did not provide significant
input on the Rev 07, Rev 08 and Rev 09 Programmes, nor
were we ever provided with a complete version of these
programmes."
And you go on.
Now, the curiosity about that is that that evidence
is almost exactly the same as Mr Grgurev's evidence, who
gives the same dates and says the same thing.  That's
why I'm interested in it.
Are you aware, as you sit there now, that actually
those statements are factually wrong?  That for example,
the rev 7 full programme in Primavera had been issued to
Specon on 15 April 2018?
A.  I don't recall that.  Sorry.
Q.  Do we take it that you were -- so when you were writing
this witness statement, at no time have you been aware
that -- and also the rev 8 -- the full programmes were
issued to Specon by the JV?
A.  No, I knew.
Q.  You knew the full programmes?
A.  Not the full programme, what SBJV gave us, because they
never gave us the full programme.
Q.  Take it from me, Mr Georgiou, it's not in dispute now.
For example, just focusing on rev 7, on 15 April 2019,
that's when the rev 7 programme was actually issued and
that was the full programme, all activities, in
Primavera, delivered to Specon.  But you didn't know
that?
A.  I don't recall that.
Q.  Can we just have another look.  I'm just wondering --
you see, it's such a -- your evidence is so similar to
Mr Grgurev's mistake that I'm just wondering whether you
actually wrote this witness statement or someone wrote
it for you and you signed it without checking?
A.  No, I did write it myself, and I checked it myself.
Q.  Could we, please, just have a quick look at that.  It
may be that you don't know anything about this.
Could we have a look at M251.  This is, again,
before your time, but I'm just showing it to you because
I'm guessing you didn't know.
Having issued the full Primavera programme, the JV
wrote to Specon on 16 May requiring them and requesting
them to put in their standalone programme for the MEP
works, based on that rev 7 programme.  You didn't know
that?
A.  Of course I didn't, I was not there.
Q.  Right.  But you're giving evidence about it.  You
actually just gave evidence about the rev 7 programme?
A.  Yes, but I didn't -- I had the programme unarranged.
Q.  You also said, with respect, that to your knowledge, no
one had had any input into that, so you've given your
evidence about it.
A.  From myself.
Q.  Could we then go forward, so again I just want to see
what else you did or didn't know.  D11332.
This is Specon some months later on 24 July 2018,
saying that they are going to claim an extension of
time.  In the second paragraph, they said:
"In compliance with your request, we submit herewith
for your review and comment a programme referenced
'Rev. 7 MEP Monitoring Programme' ..."
So you know what happens, this is not accepted, this
was for comment, and the comments were that the JV
rejected it.  But were you aware that Specon had,
shortly before your arrival, actually produced
a standalone MEP programme of its own, based on the
rev 7 programme?
A.  No, I didn't.
Q.  Were you aware that -- the answer must follow that what
then happens is that the JV rejects that programme,
saying effectively it had been tweaked to support the
EOT claim, and requiring the submission of another
programme, but Specon never provided one.  It didn't
provide a standalone programme of its own.
A.  It was not my job to prepare programmes.
Q.  Does it follow from everything we've just talked about
that you were not using whatever this programme is that
Specon had produced at any time when you arrived on
site?
A.  No, because we usually do a weekly programmes.  We never
follow any of those.
Q.  The weekly programmes, is this fair -- and we've had
evidence from the former project director about this.
The weekly programmes, were you aware that at the
outset, they were based on the rev 7 programme and they
had set -- they set targets with look-aheads which would
be month, two months sometimes.  Were you aware of that?
A.  I was aware of that.
Q.  Were you aware that those targets were coming from each
of the subcontractors in effect, including Specon?  They
would be the ones who would say what they were expecting
to do?
A.  It was not that.  It was done by SBJV trying to get
whatever out of each contractor to give it to the next
contractor.  That was the issue.  They couldn't follow
any programme.
Q.  Well, I have to suggest to you, Mr Georgiou, what was
happening was that there was -- of course the JV is
collating information and it is, from all of the
relevant subcontractors, about how they're planning to
progress their works, what they're anticipating to do
and then those updates are issued in the form of
monthly, sometimes two-monthly look-aheads and they will
go up on the war room walls as a starting point; is that
right?
A.  That's correct.
Q.  From those look-aheads, based on what each subcontractor
had said, there would then be weekly plans set out, so
that each subcontractor would then have its weekly plan
set out on the war room walls?
A.  It would be, but usually we follow it daily, because it
will never go on more than a day with accuracy, never.
Q.  Just bear with me.  In terms of planning, so is this
right, you've got plan based on look-ahead from Specon's
plan of what it wants to do, weekly targets, and then
all contractors are doing the same and it's being put up
on the walls to discuss on a daily basis; is that right?
A.  Not completely, because there was a plan that was put on
the wall, not by Specon, because Specon, it was not the
driving --
Q.  Sorry, I'm not suggesting that what is going up on the
wall -- I'm saying the JV certainly collated all of the
information from all of the different trades,
subcontractors, and then was splitting it up and putting
it on the walls.  I'm not saying you --
A.  Yes, they did, they did, they did.
Q.  I certainly was not suggesting that.
A.  No.
Q.  What then happens is that progress is being monitored
against those plans?
A.  Yes.
Q.  But the plans you're talking about are the ones that, in
your case, you would have been planning to do work in
certain rooms, on certain levels, with certain
resources, based on the month look-ahead or the
two-month look-ahead that your planning team had
discussed with the JV?
A.  This is what we tried.
Q.  I have to suggest to you, that's a perfectly logical and
sensible way to manage a complex project like this,
isn't it?
A.  No, because you cannot put 15 contractors in a room and
try to get answers in an hour in the morning from 7 to
8.  Everybody wanted to take, say his opinion, blame the
others, started shouting and so forth, as you can see in
my witness statement.
Q.  Yes, but in practice in the war rooms, what the war
rooms were effectively about was there would be handover
procedures, for example you would have internal handover
procedures for rooms and levels where you would be
getting access, and you would sign off on it, wouldn't
you?
A.  Correct.
Q.  So there's these areas that you are planning to work on,
signed over, you take them.  When they're handed to you,
you go around and you check to see whether there's any
obstacles to your work?
A.  Correct.
Q.  If there are obstacles, that's something that's got to
be reported back into the war rooms.  I imagine some of
those obstacles are things that can be sorted out almost
immediately, because someone has left their materials
and equipment in a room, you need to get it out, and
others will be more long term.  Is that right?
A.  Correct.
Q.  That's the sort of adjustment and things that's going on
on the daily basis, isn't it?
A.  It's one part of it, correct.  The other part is that
not all contractors checked, not all contractors told
the truth.
Q.  Of course.
A.  So even when we went for a site walk after the meeting
to verify those rooms, we will find out that maybe half
of them are not even ready, or they will just disappear,
because in the war room, there was an agreement,
everybody to try to be as truthful and genuine we can.
But because of that reason, there's so many contractors,
it was difficult to impossible to gain this.
So the meeting started from 7 to 8, then it would go
from 7 to 9, then you got from 7 to 9.30.
Q.  The point you're making, which is a valid one, is if you
then go out on site and discover what you're being told
is not true, you're doing immediate reporting in real
time, effectively, back to say: we don't have the access
you've been promised?
A.  You couldn't go back.  Because the war room finished.
You have to wait for the next day.
Q.  The following day you can go back?
A.  The next day, but you lost a day.
Q.  You've lost a day, but --
A.  Tomorrow you lose another day.
Q.  But the point about it is a lot of these obstacles you
can plan for, because it will be obvious that, for
example, a preceding trade has not advanced far enough
to give you the release of a certain room or series of
rooms the following Monday.  It would be obvious to you,
based on experience, wouldn't it?
A.  Correct.  Up to a point.  We demanded by SBJV to send
a team to check them before, because there was a lot of
waste of time in this procedure and a waste of the
resources.  So after the meeting, SBJV will go with our
people to check them.
Q.  But it's inevitable, isn't it, where you've got multiple
different trades on site, and you've got a fast-track
project, that you're going to have to have some sort of
process like this of granular level, very low-level
checking and progress and sorting out problems as they
arise?
A.  Correct, you should have this kind of process.  But with
this quantity of contractors, it was a struggle, to be
honest.
Q.  Could we look, please, just -- again, we don't have time
to go through everything, but just sort of some of the
information, and information prepared by Specon.  If we
could go to M327, please.
Actually, sorry, I should start before that.
M312, please.  An email from you.  Go down, please.
Sorry, from Mr Sabri and to yourself and -- keep going,
please.  I want 14 November 2018.  Keep going.  Keep
going.  Keep going.  Thank you.
So this is an email from Mr Sabri, 14 November,
directed to the project director, but you are in copy,
so you're obviously on site by this stage.
He is saying:
"Hotels Target ZERO
Zeljko,
Please note that target this week in hotels not
achieved (zero room) for the following issues:
- Additional plumbers required 60 Nos.
- We need extra supervision, Forman and supervisors.
- Site engineers ... to be rainforest with senior
engineers or CM's.
- We need 3 additional QA, QC engineers, right now
we have only one for site and office.
- I need one engineer to follow up the corridors and
back of house rooms, until now we didn't start to clear
any corridors.
- One of your planning engineers have to be full
time only for hotels.
- One month look ahead for procurement.
- Engineering department to be In line with site
target (next week target some drawing C status in
Aconex)."
So he's saying you can't -- that your shop drawings
haven't been approved yet for the work you're targeting.
He then says, and I think it should be "By the way,
Nicolas can't":
"By anyway Nicolas along can't do miracle!!!"
And I think he means that he's recognising that it's
a valuable addition to have you there, but you can't do
it all on your own and work miracles.  Is that fair?
So he's saying, basically, you need more men.
You're not hitting your targets, you haven't got your
shop drawings in order, you haven't got your materials
and you're not planning your procurement properly.  Is
that fair?
A.  That's what he's saying, correct.
Q.  Do you recall that you then discussed this.  If we go up
until we find -- sorry, 8 December, Mr Grgurev.  Keep
going, please.  Keep going.  He says -- stop, please.
He's saying that in the last paragraph, this is his
response, so we're some way down the line, he says:
"Yes, following our discussion that despite 134
plumbers and Sr. Engineers and Sr. Superintendent for
plumbing, we need some more plumbers, we have already
taken action, and you will see plumbers gradually
increasing from tomorrow morning, when people inducted
today will join.
No, we do not believe that night shift is a right
way forward at this moment.  Extended day shift and work
on Friday will be authorized and implemented instead."
So Specon, at least at this stage, are recognising
they need more resources and that they are falling
behind?
A.  Correct.
Q.  If we go up the email chain, please -- sorry, go down
a little bit, please -- no, stop there.  On 5 January,
Mr Sabri is chasing you for a reply.  He says:
"Nicolas,
One month from last email and almost 2 months from
first email and still we have shortage of supervision
and plumbers.
Where your plan for corridors and back of house
rooms?
Why until now we have shortage of materials, where
the one month look ahead procurement schedule?"
So he's saying, quite pointedly, what's going on?
Why haven't you done anything?  It's been two months.
He's putting a lot of pressure on you to perform; is
that right?
A.  This is what his email says.
Q.  He's right; you hadn't responded?
A.  I have responded, yeah.
Q.  No, in a moment you do.
A.  Sorry?
Q.  We'll see.  You respond seven days later.
A.  Yeah.
Q.  You haven't -- I don't mean you personally, I mean
Specon --
A.  Yeah, I understand, I understand, it's clear, it's
clear.  But if you can see from this email, he's
referring to the corridors and the back.  That problem
of the corridors and the back of house, it was until the
day Specon was terminated.
Q.  That's not the point, Mr Georgiou.  What is being said
here, accepted by Specon, is there is a shortage of men,
the materials aren't being procured in a sensible plan,
and as a result, you're not making progress.  And he
wants a positive plan for how you're going to recover it
and get on properly.  That's what he's asking for?
A.  I purely disagree with Wassim and I had been done since
most of the project because he always used to exaggerate
on situations.  And as you can see from his email, this
is he's talking for a specific area, which, yes,
I realise it was the corridors and the common room back
of house, which was a problem created in such by SBJV
regarding the cantilevers, the skybridges and the
blockworks in the back of house of the contractor.  But
the rest, it was going smoothly.
Q.  Can you go up, please, to the email, your response:
"We apologise for the late reply.
We have received another 24 plumbers in the last
couple of weeks and we have exceeded the number we have
agreed."
Finally, after two months, you have got some
additional resources to what had been agreed; is that
right?
A.  No.  That's 24, then we gradually received more people
in the meantime.  The receiving of people never stopped.
If we didn't receive them, SBJV will force them.
Q.  It says:
"However a separate team is being formed for the
rectification works for the accessibility of the
valves ..."
Is this right, if you need a separate team, there's
some significant rectification works to be done in
Specon's work; is that right?
A.  That's correct.
Q.  Then you say:
"This will be finalised in the next couple of days
since the program has been send yesterday.
Regarding the corridors we still have issues for the
inspections for the wall clearances because of the sub
riser drawings which our technical department is
preparing ..."
So the problem, is this right, is back with
Mr Al Taki and his engineering team at Specon?
A.  Not purely.  I can explain the riser, what was the
problem.  Want me to?
Q.  Yes.
A.  The problem with the risers is that there was both sides
of the wall, the one side of the wall it couldn't be
closed so the riser can progress, but potentially,
because of Ishtar couldn't build up the walls in the
corridor, we cannot support the pipes.  So it was going
hand in hand with the blockwork installation.  So that
was the problem with it.
Q.  The problem that you are reporting is it's your
technical department which you're waiting on in order to
be able to clear the backlog?
A.  Correct, they were trying to fix the problem that
created by the contractors.
Q.  Then you say:
"As far as the materials are concern we have place
most of the orders for the complete hotel and we are
waiting confirmation from the supplier in the meanwhile
we are ordering as per target room requirements."
You're saying now we have got a procurement plan in
place; is that right?
A.  Yes, correct.
Q.  If we go through to M327.  If we could go -- do you
